awd_titl_txt: PI Meeting: The Future of Work at the Human Technology Frontier: Advancing Cognitive and Physical Capabilities; Alexandria, Virginia; April 5, 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a one-day workshop convening an interdisciplinary group of experts conducting research on the relationship between workers, emerging technologies, and the social and economic landscape of jobs and work. Participants will report on the first year of their NSF-supported projects, as well as participate in structured and unstructured activities, including oral presentations, poster sessions, and panel discussions, to facilitate the exchange of ideas and experiences. The applications areas that will be covered by the workshop participants range from power grid resiliency to medical decision making to classroom education to factory work to firefighting. These projects go beyond the introduction of new technology into the workplace, and explicitly address the social and economic consequences of innovation.

All twelve projects supported under the FY2018 solicitation NSF 18-548, "Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier: Advancing Cognitive and Physical Capabilities (FW-HTF)," will be represented at the workshop. Other participants will include representatives of previous NSF-supported projects and researchers from academia, government, and industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of the 2019 PI workshop was to help the FW-HTF teams communicate their efforts to advance the state-of-the-art in several scientific disciplines such as behavioral & cognitive sciences, human factors, learning sciences, education & workforce training, engineering, computer science, and social & economic sciences. A second objective was to structure discussion and panel sessions around convergence research itself, to help each team in formulating strategies to achieve a convergent research approach, by integrating and meaningfully relating future work, future technology, and future workers in a cohesive effort, in which all three elements can be recognized, but none can be isolated from the others. While each project is driven by the specific problem of improving the future of work in its individual context, this workshop aimed to provide an opportunity to promote deep integration across disciplines that may lead to the formation of new frameworks, paradigms or even disciplines.

The workshop included opening and closing remarks from the NSF, a keynote session, three oral presentation sessions by PI teams, two panel discussions and a poster session. The keynote was presented by Mark Lewandowski, Robotics Innovation at Proctor & Gamble, focused on his experiences in leading the integration of front-line robotics technologies in manufacturing, and covering topics such as advances in robotics and AI. This was followed by awardees from the 2017 FW-HTF program that supported workshop/research coordination networks (RCNs), and from 2018 HTF project awards, covering a broad portfolio of topics of interest to the HTF mission. A panel titled 'Breaking down barriers to convergence research' then followed. Featuring 6 panelists, this panel included discussions on the successes and failures in mechanisms and communication channels that different teams had adopted during their award period until date; bench-marked the extent to which those practices had opened up new convergence research questions that each researcher could have not solved independently, measurable indicators of convergence; and finally concluded with highlighting challenges in modifying/adapting research methodologies and dissemination channels (e.g., target journals) to accommodate, and even foster, convergence research. The panel session on augmented reality (AR) followed: since a majority of the FW-HTF 2018 projects seek to utilize augmented reality in their research projects, the panel featured presentations and discussions on the state of the art and challenges in augmented reality from 4 leading experts in the field, to benefit all involved and foster connections and collaboration across PI teams, to solve common scientific and technical AR-related challenges that were being encountered by several teams. 

The projects supported by this program, and presented at the PI workshop, ranged across a diverse array of applications such as control room operators, manufacturing workers, teachers, firefighters, civil infrastructure inspectors, vehicle operators, medical personnel and shift workers. By learning about projects and communicating best-practices across teams that study human-technology interaction within the broader socio-economic framework of jobs and work, this workshop furthered understanding of the FW-HTF program's mission and impacted all the supported research projects and individual researchers to think more broadly about processes and outcomes. The deep understanding of the opportunities and limitations of physical and cognitive augmentation technology across diverse users opened up some foundational thoughts and discussions for the formulation of future training programs and instructional research. Finally, in addition to reframing the context of new technology development with explicit attention to workforce diversity, the workshop led to better understanding of actionable deployments of appropriate technology and training to enhance the social and economic well-being of the country as a whole.
